Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Issue: Entitlement to refugee status under IRPA sections 96 and 97
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) sections 96, 97, and 72
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Haiti in 1991, lived illegally in the US for 15 years without seeking asylum, and applied for refugee status in Canada in 2006 claiming persecution due to Lavalas party involvement
Decision_Outcome: Application for refugee status denied; judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division's decision
Claimant_Status: Haitian national, previously residing illegally in the US
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to apply for asylum during prolonged stay in the US
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution based on political opinion (Lavalas party)
Legal_Standard: Credibility, subjective fear, particularized risk, Convention grounds
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of claim, length of time in another country without seeking protection, generalized vs. particularized risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under section 72 of IRPA
Credibility_Assessment: Claim lacked credible evidence; inconsistent behavior undermined credibility
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, country condition reports on Haiti
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 96 (refugee definition), s. 97 (protection), s. 72 (judicial review)
Application_Basis: Claim of persecution due to political opinion in Haiti
Evidence_Assessed: Applicantâ€™s delay in seeking protection, lack of documentation supporting political involvement
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person and grant of refugee status
Governing_Rule: Board must assess credibility, subjective fear, and particularized risk; generalized violence insufficient
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of active Lavalas involvement, no attempt to seek asylum in the US
Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; application for judicial review dismissed
Harm_Assessment: Fear of generalized violence in Haiti, not linked to a Convention ground
Cause_Description: Applicant fled Haiti in 1991, resided unlawfully in the US for 15 years, then sought refugee status in Canada in 2006 based on alleged political persecution
Evidence_Handling: Board evaluated applicant's testimony and found it lacking in credibility and corroboration
Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly violated; failure to satisfy IRPA s. 96 requirements
Evidence_Issues: Lack of corroborative evidence, inconsistencies in timeline and behavior
Residency_Compliance: Unlawful presence in the United States for 15 years
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation by omission regarding asylum opportunities in the US
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether Canadian refugee protection applies given prolonged stay in third country
Evidence_Assessment: Testimony deemed insufficient to establish a well-founded fear on a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: Generalized country conditions do not constitute persecution; applicant failed to demonstrate particularized risk or credible fear
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence to prove political activism or targeted risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on a Convention ground under IRPA s. 96
